section.title: What is "pcb-fpw" ?
section.para: "pcb-fpw" is a FootPrintWizard for "pcb".
"fpw" (FootPrintWizard) is a Command Line Interface program for the (automated) creation of footprint files used by the pcb layout editor for the placement of parts in a pcb layout.
"pcb-gfpw" is a GTK GUI version for the interactive creation of footprint files used by the pcb layout application for the placement of parts in a pcb layout.

section.title: What is "pcb" ?
section.para: "pcb" pcb is an interactive Printed Circuit Board editor for the X11 window system (see "http://pcb.geda-project.org".

PCB includes a rats nest feature, design rule checking, and can provide industry standard RS-274-X (Gerber), NC drill, and centroid data (X-Y data) output for use in the board fabrication and assembly process.
PCB offers high end features such as an autorouter, topological router and trace optimizer which can tremendously reduce layout time.

section.title: How to read this manual.
section.para: This manual is organized as follows:
Throughout this manual, words in
Typewriter Fontdenote a command given in the Command Line Interface in a (terminal) shell window.
Throughout this manual, words in literal font denote keywords recognized by pcb-fpw.
In the input entries of the GUI versions of pcb-fpw, these have to be typed as shown, but may be in upper or lower case.
Numbers or options which must be supplied by the user are in italic.

In some cases, various different forms of input values are possible. This is indicated as [option1, option2, ... , optionN]. In the GUI version of pcb-fpw these values can be entered in a (text) entry box.
In some cases only one single (mutual exclusive) preset value can be used. In the GUI version of pcb-fpw a combobox is used for selecting one of these possible (mutual exclusive) preset options.
The possible options are described individually in subsequent subsections.
It is essential for the new user to read the next section in this chapter, in order to understand the conventions used to define the footprint an footprinwizard files, and so on.
The next chapter gives an overview of the various building and installation methods for pcb-fpw. Pick the one that suits you best.
The later chapters, which describe the input of the individual program modules in detail, assume that you are familiar with the concepts of footprint and footprintwizard files.

section.title: Terms and definitions.
section.para: Now follow some used terms and their definitions in relation to the context of pcb-fpw, and usage in pcb-fpw. For a more extensive glossary of pcb terms and definitions see Appendix A "PCB Glossary".

glossdef.para: A footprint may have attributes assigned to them, which are arbitrary mappings between a name and its value..
The distance beween the copper around a hole (the annulus) and the copper in the surrounding polygon, or between any other copper item (line or arc) and a surrounding polygon.
The area around a footprint which is still "used" by the footprint, for its electrical and mechanical clearance requirements..

A set of fiducials (typically 2, sometimes 3) can serve as a reference for a "Pick-and-Place" machine to accurately place parts on a pcb. Fiducials are free of solder mask and solder paste, as to provide a good contrast with the board materials to allow for proper optical recognition.

A footprint is the pattern on a circuit board to which your parts are attached. This includes all copper, silk, solder mask, and solder paste information. In other EDA programs, this may be referred to as a "land pattern". "Footprint" sometimes is used to refer to a footprint file. "Footprint" refers to the pattern; "element" refers to the instance in the pcb file. For example, your layout might have four elements that use one footprint.
A file that contains a single footprint definition. Normally, this means it describes one element, although there are exceptions.
A mil is 0.001 inch, or a "milli-inch". Other packages may call it a "thou", short for a thousandth of an inch (25.4 mm / 1000 = 0.0254 mm).
The physical shape and dimension of your physical package. By default, this is a rectangle, but this can be circular as well.
An electronic component can be packaged in one or more discrete forms, this is called a package.
An electrical connection to an element which does not require a through hole, for example as used by a surface mounted device.

An electrical connection to an element which requires a through hole, for example as needed by a DIP socket. Contrast with a pad. Note that pins and vias are mechanically identical, although pins default to untented while vias default to tented.

glossentry.glossterm: plated hole, plated through hole, PTH

glossdef.para: During fabrication, some holes become coated with copper which connects all the copper layers together at that point. Since this is normally done by electroplating, such holes are called "plated" holes, and normally have a copper annulus around them.
A layer of ink or pigment drawn on the circuit board (usually, one for each side of the board) in order to include, for example, part numbers or element outlines.

A layer of heat resistant film placed over the outermost copper layers of your board, to prevent solder from sticking to any covered copper. When used to cover traces routed between pins or pads, this can help avoid shorts to those traces. Note that when shown in pcb the mask is drawn where the film exists, but when output (to postscript or gerber, for example), it is often "drawn" where the mask is to be removed.

Ground up solder mixed with flux. This paste is normally squeegeed through a paste stencil to deposit a measured amount of paste on each pad on the board. Once the paste is applied, parts can be positioned on the paste, and the board heated - which melts the paste and solders the parts to the board.

Since copper is an efficient heat sink, connections to a large region of copper would be very difficult to solder - the copper heat sink prevents you from adequately heating the connection. Thermals come in many patterns, which allows the designer to ensure adequate electrical connectivity and/or manufacturability.

During fabrication, some holes are drilled after electroplating, and so do not receive the copper that would otherwise connect layers. Such holes are unplated holes, and normally do not have a copper annulus around them either.

chapter.title: Building and installation of pcb-fpw.
chapter.para: Now follows a detailed description of the various installation methods available for the pcb footprintwizard.

sect1.title: Dependencies.
sect1.para: The building and installation process of pcb-fpw from scratch, either from a tarball/zipball, or from the git repository, requires (at least):

listitem.para: autoconf >= 2.63
automake >= 1.9.6
pkg-config >= 0.9.0
libtool >= 1.5.22
libglade2 >= 2.5.1
cairo >= 1.0.4
gettext >= 0.16.1
libpng >= 1.2.44.
git >= 1.7.3.4 (optional)
tar >= 1.22 (optional)
gzip >= 1.3.13 (optional)
unzip >= 6.0.2 (optional)

note.para: Your Mileage May Vary with lesser version numbers, these are the minimum versions used to develop pcb-fpw.

sect1.title: Building and installation from the main git repository.
sect1.para: When building and installation of pcb-fpw for development purposes is required, then the pcb-fpw source tree and files can be installed from the main git git repository at Github, or any other fork of this repository.
This requires cloning into a local repository, which can be done with the following command:
git clone git://github.com/bert/pcb-fpw.gitThe above command will create a directory "pcb-fpw", and then download and extract all needed files into this directory.
If you clone from a forked repository at Github the git URI will have a different value, as can be noticed by the instructions given during the "forking" process on Github.com.
After the download of the source files is done sucessfully, change to the pcb-fpw directory with:
cd pcb-fpwThe actual building and installation of pcb-fpw can start with the following sequence of commands:

Installation will require su (root) privileges. Depending on user requirements another prefix directory than /usr/local/ can be used, for instance when the user has no root privileges for installing in a system directory, the user can install in his/her home directory with --prefix=$HOME/bin/ or --prefix=$HOME/pcb-fpw/.
If the building and installation process have gone without errors, two executable binary files should result: /usr/local/bin/fpw and /usr/local/bin/pcb-gfpw.

note.para: To uninstall pcb-fpw use the following command:
This may require autogen and configure to be run first.
If so, please (re)configure with the correct prefix directory.

sect1.title: Building and installation using a tarball/zipball.
sect1.para: When building and installation of the source files using a tarball tarball / zipball zipball is required, these can be obtained from:

https://github.com/bert/pcb-fpw/downloads
https://launchpad.net/pcb-fpw/+download
Download and unpack the tarballzipball in a directory of choice with the following commands:
tar -xvzf pcb-fpw-0.0.12.tar.gzor
After unpacking the tarball/zipball successful, change to the pcb-fpw directory with:
cd pcb-fpwThe building and installation can start with the following sequence of commands:

Depending on user requirements another prefix directory than /usr/local/ can be used, for instance when the user has no root privileges for installing in a system directory, the user can install in his/her home directory with --prefix=$HOME/bin/ or --prefix=$HOME/pcb-fpw/.
If the building and installation process have gone without errors, two executable binary files should result: /usr/local/bin/fpw and /usr/local/bin/pcb-gfpw.

note.para: To uninstall pcb-fpw use the following command:
This may require autogen and configure to be run first.
If so, please (re)configure with the correct prefix directory.

sect1.title: Installation using a rpm package file.
sect1.para: When installation of the pcb-fpw using a rpm package rpm package file containing pre-build (executable) binaries is required, the needed rpm file can be obtained from:

listitem.para: https://github.com/bert/pcb-fpw/downloads
https://launchpad.net/pcb-fpw/+download

sect1.para: Install the rpm package with su privileges with:
To update a previously installed version of pcb-fpw:
rpm -Uvh pcb-fpw-0.0.12.fc13.i686.rpmThis will Upgrade while giving verbose information and printing the progress with hashmarks.

note.para: For now the pcb-fpw rpm package is not relocatable.

For more information on the man-page of rpm - RPM Package Manager do:

sect1.title: Building and packaging using a srpm package file.
sect1.para: When installation of the pcb-fpw using a srpm package srpm package file containing the source tree and a specification file is required, the needed srpm file can be obtained from:

listitem.para: https://github.com/bert/pcb-fpw/downloads
https://launchpad.net/pcb-fpw/+download

sect1.para: Install the srpm package with:
The above command will extract a specification file in $HOME/rpmbuild/SPEC and the tarball in $HOME/rpmbuild/SOURCES.
Change the current directory into rpmbuild with:
cd $HOME/rpmbuildBuild a binary rpm with su (root) privileges with:
rpmbuild -bb SPEC/pcb-fpw.specInstall you rpm with:

note.para: In the above command an "i686" architecture was used, this may vary with the architecture of the targetted host machine.

sect1.title: Installation using yum.
sect1.para: Yum yum , the Yellowdog Updater Modified, can be used to install local downloaded rpm packages as well.
After dowloading the rpm file from the URI listed in the previous sections, installation can be done with the following command:
yum localinstall pcb-fpw-0.0.12.fc13.i686.rpmor:
yum localupdate pcb-fpw-0.0.12.fc13.i686.rpmfor updating a previously installed version of pcb-fpw.

note.para: A yum repo definition file can be downloaded from http://ljh4timm.home.xs4all.nl/pcb-fpw/repo and installed into /etc/yum.repos.d/.
The file "pcb-fpw.repo" will configure yum for installing and updating future versions of pcb-fpw.

chapter.title: Intended usage.
chapter.para: The "pcb-fpw" FootPrintWizard is what the name says it will be at most: a footprint wizard (a.k.a. footprint generator).

pcb-fpw is not a footprint editor, therefor one can NOT load an existing footprint file into pcb-gfpw, make some changes and save it back to file, and subsequent load the edited footprint file into pcb.

section.title: Synopsis.
section.para: fpw [options]
fpw [options] -f INPUT_FILE -o OUTPUT_FILE
fpw [options] --format INPUT_FILE --output OUTPUT_FILE

section.title: Description.
section.para: The Command Line Interface program "fpw" can be used for the batch-wise generation of footprint files.
The generation of the footprint file is based on a definition file (file extension is typically ".fpw") containing values in a set order, that is the position of a value in the file has a meaning.
The generated output file is a footprint file (file extension is typically ".fp") compatible with the printed circuit board layout editor program "pcb" (see http://pcb.geda-project.org)

section.title: Options.
section.para: The fpw program accepts the following options:

listitem.para: Print this help message and exit.
Log messages, be verbose.
Do not log messages, overrides --verbose.
Print the version information and exit.
Specify a footprintwizard input filename.
Specify a footprint output filename.
Turn on debugging output messages.

section.title: Examples.
section.para: <to be done>

section.title: Notes.
section.para: <to be done>

section.title: Using the GTK User Interface (pcb-gfpw).
section.para: For the interactive design and graphical oriented users there is a Graphical User Interface based on the Gimp ToolKit (GTK).
There is a short tracked explanation of pcb-gfpw in the following section "In a nutshell".
Users that need a more detailed manual can keep on reading in "Starting the application" and "Using the main window".

section.title: In a nutshell.
section.para: In a nutshell, the usage of pcb-gfpw comes down to the following:

Startup the application.
Fill the apropriate entries in:
The "Author" tab.
The "Footprint" tab.
The "Pins/pads" tab.
The "Silkscreen" tab.
The "Thermal pad" tab.
The "Heel & Toe goals" tab.
Check the footprint in the preview window (when and if this is implemented) by pressing the "Preview" button.
Generate and save the footprint to file by pressing the "Footprint" button.
Save the footprintwizard file (for future reuse or debugging) by pressing the "Save" button.
In the folowing sections the above actions will be discussed in more detail.

section.title: Starting up the application.
section.para: The application can be started by selecting from the start menu, or by entering "pcb-gfpw" from the Command Line Interface in a (terminal) shell window.

note.para: Adding an ampersand character ("&") at the end of the command will run pcb-gfpw from a background process, this will return the command prompt to the (terminal) shell for subsequent commands.

section.para: During the startup of the application an "About pcb-gfpw" dialog window appears, shortly followed by the "main window" dialog window. The "About pcb-fpw" dialog window.
The "About pcb-gfpw" dialog contains the following buttons:

listitem.para: The "Credits" button: clicking this button raises a credits popup dialog in which a message about the names of the authors or translators are given (you can select the tab of your choice for more information). The "Credits" dialog window.
The "License" button: clicking this button raises a license popup dialog in which a message about the license is given under which pcb-gfpw is distributed.
The "Close" button: clicking this button closes the "About pcb-gfpw" dialog.

section.title: Using the "main window".
section.para: The main window of the program consists of five tabs with each several entry fields and a preview drawing area (when and if implemented), and a button bar with five buttons on the lower part of the window.
The titlebar shows the name of a saved footprintwizard file or the text "Unsaved fpw file" if no file has been saved, in the top of the window.
An asterisk between brackets "[*]" is shown when the contents of any entry or the state of any checkbutton are changed and no saving has occurred.
The statusbar in the bottom of the window shows information, warnings and errors, if and when, for as long as they occur.

section.title: The "Author" tab.
section.para: Now follow some entries about the "Author" and licensing of the footprint file.

listitem.para: The "Author" entry can optionally contain your name and/or e-mail address.
The "Distribution license" entry can be used to refer to the license under which the footprint is released.
As pcb-fpw comes under the GPL this is a default value which can be changed as required.
The "Use license" entry can be used to specify the usage under which the footprint may be used.
The default value is "unlimited" which can be changed, as required, to whatever restrictions you want to impose on the usage.
Examples: "unlimited", "commercial", "non-commercial", "personal", ...
The "Add license to footprint" checkbutton can be used to include a license text in the header of the footprint file.

note.para: For now this is a hard coded text resembling the exception for symbols as with gschem, or fonts in general.<add link to "footprint_licensing.xml">.

listitem.para: The "Status" entry can be used to specify the status of the footprint.
Predefined choices are: "Experimental", "Private (not published)", "Public (released)", "Stable (confirmed by peers)", ... and whatever other status you can think of.

section.title: The "Footprint" tab.

figure.title: The "Footprint" tab in the main window.

section.para:
The first tab with entries is named "Footprint" and can be used for the input of general information about the footprint.
At the entry named "Type" the footprint type is entered by selecting a footprint type from a predefined list.
The program will use this as a prefix for the footprint name if no footprint name is entered yet, or an existing prefix is altered.
The pcb-fpw program will try to guess which entries are needed for this footprint type and "grey out" the entries and checkbuttons which it thinks are not needed.
The footprint types follow a "well known and standard" footprint naming convention.
Entering no footprint type, that is a blank entry, will leave pcb-gfpw clueless on how to generate a footprint.
Only the prefix part of the "well known and standard" footprint naming convention is used.
The actual data for creating footprints relies on vendor specific datasheets (both method and content).
The entry named "Name" will contain the name that the actual footprint file will get when the footprint is saved to disk.
Add characters here to complete the footprint name.
If the footprint name contains additional characters , changing the footprint type will not update the prefix from the "Type" entry.
If the footpint name has a question mark as prefix, the program will try to lookup values for the indicated footprint.
The footprint name should be entered without the ".fp" suffix.
This is a mandatory entry, leaving this entry empty or filled with a non valid footprint name will NOT result in a footprint file when the "Save" button is clicked.
In the entry named "Units" the units for the footprint dimensions can be selected.
Currently only "mil/100", "mil" and "mm" are supported.
pcb-fpw will apply the chosen unit type for all dimensions entered in the following entries.
Changing the units type will not change the following entries automagickly, that is: if you switch the units type halfway the entries, you will have to do the math yourself.
This is a mandatory field, leaving this entry empty or filled with a non valid unit type will NOT result in a footprint file when the "Save" button is clicked.
The "Refdes prefix" entry can be used to add an optional reference designator prefix to the footprint.
Example: "R" for a resistor.
The prefix must be entered without the question mark "?".
The "Value" entry can be used to add an optional value to the footprint.
Example: "100k" for the resistor mentioned above.
The "Body length (X)" entry is used for entering the length of the package in the X-direction.
This dimension is used for the silkscreen artwork when this is checked on the tab "Silkscreen".
The "Body width (Y)" entry is used for entering the width of the package in the Y-direction.
This dimension is used for the silkscreen artwork when this is checked on the tab "Silkscreen".
The "Body heigth (Z)" entry is used for entering the heigth of the package in the Z-direction.
This dimension is NOT used for the silkscreen artwork when this is checked on the tab "Silkscreen".
This dimension entry is here for future use of the height attribute of a package.
The "Radial package" checkbutton can be used to indicate whether the package has a circular outline as opposed to a rectangular outline.
The default value for a package outline is a rectagular package for any undefined package types entered in the "Type" entry and this checkbutton not to be checked.
In all cases defined package types entered in the "Type" entry, pcb-fpw follows the design rules for this package type.
The "Add attributes to footprint" checkbutton can be used to include all values as in the entries, and the state of all check and toggle buttons as attributes in the footprint file.
This is to allow for future reference, Design Rule Checking (DRC), Electrical Rule Checking (ERC), and whatever other future purpose you can think of.

section.title: The "Pins/pads" tab.
section.para:
The "Pins/Pads" tab in the main window.
The second tab is named "Pins/Pads" and should be used for the input of information about the number and pattern of pins and/or pads, the shape and clearances.
The first group of entries is for defining a "Pattern" of pins and/or pads.

listitem.para: The "Total Pins and Pads" entry is used for displaying the total amount of pins and pads entered in other entries.
It is "greyed out" most of the time, and could have been a label widget as well.
The "Columns" entry is used for entering the number of columns of pins/pads in a footprint.
Example: the number of columns in a "PLCC" package is 2.
The "Rows" entry is used for entering the number of rows of pins/pads in a footprint.
Example: the number of rows in a "PLCC" package is 2.
The "Pitch X-direction" entry is used for entering the pitch of the pins/pads in the X-direction.
Example: the pitch in the X-direction (as in a row) for a "PLCC" package is 1.27 mm or 50 mil.
The "Pitch Y-direction" entry is used for entering the pitch of the pins/pads in the Y-direction.
Example: the pitch in the Y-direction (as in a column) for a "PGA" package is 2.54 mm or 100 mil.
The "Count X-direction" entry is used for entering the number of pins/pads on a row (the X-direction).
The "Count Y-direction" entry is used for entering the number of pins/pads on a column (the Y-direction).
The "Pin/pads #1 position" entry is used for entering the location of the #1 pin and/or pad of the package.
It contains pre-defined locations, which can be chosen by clicking the arrow of the combobox. <add link to "pin_pad_1_locations.xml" here>

The "Pin/pads exceptions" entry is used for entering the pins or pads that are not present at the package. All exceptions are to be specified individually by a row indicator where the indicator is one or more letters of the alphabet ([A .. Y, AA .. YY] etc. excluding "I", "O", "Q", "S" and "Z"), and a column indicator where the indicator is a member of the positive Natural numbers (N).
Each exception is separated by a comma (",").
No wildcards ["?","*"] or collections [A1-A5","B2-B6"] allowed for now, this is left for a future enhancement, and kudos if you send in a patch with a (fully tested) solution ;-)
Currently the limit is set to a maximum of 10.000 leads, and/or 80 rows (this limit is hard coded for now).
For entering large amounts of exceptions on BGA or PGA footprints, there is a select exception dialog available.
This select exception dialog is invoked by clicking the button left of the text entry. The "Select exceptions" dialog window.
The above example shows that only the outer two rows/columns of leads of a 100 pad (10 rows by 10 columns) BGA package (or all pins for a PGA package) are present.

The 36 exceptions are withdrawn from the total number of pins/pads, and this is reflected in the "total pins and pads" entry after the "refresh" button is clicked.
The "Close" button will ignore all changes and close the dialog.
The "Clear" button will clear all ticks from check boxes in the dialog.
This means that there will be no leads present on this package.
The "OK" button will accept all changes and close the dialog.

section.para:
The second group of entries "Pins" is used for the dimensions of pins (only).
The "Pin pad diameter (D)" entry is used for entering the outer diameter of the annulus of the pin.
The "Pin drill diameter (d)" entry is used for entering the inner diameter of the annulus of the pin.
This is also known as the drill diameter.
The "Pin #1 square" check button is used for selecting a round or a square #1 pin.

The last group of entries "Pads" is used for the dimensions of pads (only).
The "Pad shape" entry is used for selecting the shape of the pad.
It contains pre-defined pad shapes.
The "Pad length (X)" entry is used for entering the length of the pad (in the X-direction).
The "Pad width (Y)" entry is used for entering the width of the pad (in the Y-direction).
The "Pad clearance" entry is used for entering the clearance between the pad and other (conductive) copper traces or (polygon) surfaces.
The "Pad solder mask clearance" entry is used for entering the distance between the pad (copper) and the solder mask (solder resist).

section.title: The "Silkscreen" tab.
section.para:
The "Silkscreen" tab in the main window.
The fourth tab is named "Silkscreen" and can be used for the input of an optional silkscreen to be drawn, such as package outline, pin/pad #1 marker and/or courtyard.
The first group of entries "Package" is used for the drawing of the artwork on the silkscreen.

listitem.para: The "Print package outline" check button is used for selecting or deselecting whether the footprint contains a package outline.
The "Pad #1 indicator" check button is used for selecting or deselecting whether the footprint contains a pin #1 indicator.
The "Line width" entry is used for entering the line width of the package outline.

section.para: The second group of entries "Courtyard" is used for the dimensions of the courtyard.

listitem.para: The "Print Courtyard" check box is used for selecting or deselecting printing of a courtyard on the footprint.
The "Length or diameter (X)" entry is used for entering the length or diameter of the courtyard.
The "Width (Y)" entry is used for entering the width of the courtyard.
The "Line width" entry is used for entering the line width of the courtyard.
The "Clearance with package" entry is used for entering the clearance between the package outline and the package itself.

section.title: The "Thermal pad" tab.

figure.title: The "Thermal pad" tab in the main window.

section.para: The third tab is named "Thermal pad" and can be used for an optional thermal pad and fiducials, if the footprint type allows for such an option.
The first group of entries "Thermal Pad" is used for the dimensions of thermal pad(s) (only).

listitem.para: The "Thermal pad" check button is used for selecting or deselecting a thermal pad on the footprint.
The "No paste on pad" check button is used for selecting paste or no paste on the thermal pad of the footprint.
The "Pad length (X)" entry is used for entering the length of the thermal pad (in the X-direction).
The "Pad width (Y)" entry is used for entering the width of the thermal pad (in the Y-direction).
The "Pad clearance" entry is used for entering the clearance between the thermal pad and other (conductive) copper traces or (polygon) surfaces.
The "Pad solder mask clearance" entry is used for entering the distance between the thermal pad (copper) and the solder mask (solder resist).

section.para:
The second group of entries "Fiducials" is used for the dimensions of fiducials (only).
The "Fiducials" check box is used for selecting or deselecting fiducials on the footprint
The "Fiducial pad diameter (D)" entry is used for entering the diameter of the fiducial pads.
The "Fiducial pad clearance" entry is used for entering the clearance between the fiducial pad and other (conductive) copper traces or (polygon) surfaces.
The "Fiducial solder mask clearance" entry is used for entering the distance between the fiducial pad (copper) and the solder mask (solder resist).

section.title: The "Heel & Toe goals" tab.
section.para:
The "Heel & Toe goals" tab in the main window.
The fifth and last tab is named "Heel & Toe goals".
This tab is for the input of heel and toe parameters to allow for the creation of PLCC, SO, QFN or QFP packages.
The first group of entries "Top to Bottom" is used for entering the distance between the top and bottom rows of pads.

The "Inner-Inner (G1)" check button is used for activating the "inner-inner" distance entry.
This is also known as the "Heel to Heel" distance.
The "Center-Center (C1)" check button is used for activating the "center-center" distance entry.
The "Outer-Outer (Z1)" check button is used for activating the "outer-outer" distance entry.
This is also known as the "Toe to Toe" distance.
The second group of entries "Left to Right" is used for entering the distance between the left and right columns of pads.

listitem.para: The "Inner-Inner (G2)" check button is used for activating the "inner-inner" distance entry.
This is also known as the "Heel to Heel" distance.
The "Center-Center (C2)" check button is used for activating the "center-center" distance entry.
The "Outer-Outer (Z2)" check button is used for activating the "outer-outer" distance entry.
This is also known as the "Toe to Toe" distance.

section.title: The buttons.
section.para: The eight buttons in the lower part have the following functions:

listitem.para: "Refresh": to refresh all entries.
"Dimensions": to view a dimensions legenda in a popup dialog.
"Preview": to view the footprint in a popup preview dialog (when and if implemented).
"Clear": to empty all entry fields and reset all check boxes to the default setting.
"Close": to exit the application.
"Open": to choose and read an existing footprintwizard file.
"Footprint": to write the current values in the entries to a footprint file.
"Save": to write the current values in the entries to a footprintwizard file.

section.title: A word about Licensing.
section.para: All software components of pcb-fpw are released under the GNU General Public License (GPL) version 2 or later.
However, some confusion exists about the generated footprints.

What license do they use? Will GPL footprints "infect" your design, thereby requiring you to release your design to the public ? If you modify the footprints, must you release the modified versions under the GPL ?

The goal of the pcb-fpw Project is to provide open-source EDA Tools with footprints which may be used for non-commerical as well as commercial projects. Our tools are aimed for use by students, hobbyists, educators, consultants, and -- yes -- corporate engineers. We are not interested in exerting any control over your designs, or forcing you to reveal proprietary information contained in your designs.

Footprints are similar to the font files used in document processing software -- they are graphical objects used to express your ideas. We want you to retain control of your own ideas (your design), while the pcb-fpw Project retains a say in how you redistribute the footprints, generated with pcb-fpw tools, themselves.
There are three ways a footprint might be distributed:

listitem.para: As part of a (bundled) footprint wizard file library, or individually as a .fpw file (i.e. as a footprint wizard file itself).
As part of a footprint library, or individually as a .fp file (i.e. as a footprint itself).
Embedded in a .pcb file (i.e. part of the soft, or editable copy of a design).
The resulting graphical expression on a gerber file or printout of the pcb layout (i.e. as part of the hard, or non-editable copy of a design).

section.para: There is a distinction between cases (1, 2) and (3, 4).
In case (1, 2) the object of interest is the (bundled) footprint wizard file (library) (or individual footprint) itself.
In case (3, 4), the object of interest is the design.
Some label case (1, 2) "distribution", and case (3, 4) "use" of the footprint (wizard) file.

Our goals for the footprints are:
We wish to distribute the footprints and footprint wizard files under a licencing scheme which encourages that you give back to the community if you redistribute the footprints or footprint wizard files themselves -- whether modified or unmodified.
This is case (1, 2) distribution. The GPL ensures this.
We wish to specifically prohibit anybody from building pcb-fpw's footprints into their *software* products, and then place restrictions on how the resulting product may be used. If you bundle footprints or footprint wizard files -- whether modified or unmodified -- into your software and then distribute it, then you must allow for the software's (and footprint's) continued redistribution under the GPL.
Again, this is case (1, 2) distribution; the GPL ensures this.
However, we do not wish to "infect" your *electronic* design, or force you to release your proprietary design information if you use or embedd footprints in your design.
This is case (3, 4) use.
The Free Software Foundation has recognized a possible conflict of the base GPL with the use of fonts -- and, by analogy, footprints used in case (3, 4).
Their solution is to use an exemption clause in the GPL which you explicitly insert for fonts.
Read about it here: "http://www.fsf.org/licensing/licenses/gpl-faq.html#FontException"
Therefore, using this as a template, all footprints released with pcb-fpw are covered under the GPL with the following exception clause:

para.quote: As a special exception, if you create a design which uses this footprint, and embed this footprint or unaltered portions of this footprint into the design, this footprint does not by itself cause the resulting design to be covered by the GNU General Public License. This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why the design itself might be covered by the GNU General Public License. If you modify this footprint, you may extend this exception to your version of the footprint, but you are not obligated to do so. If you do not wish to do so, delete this exception statement from your version.

section.para: The idea is that case (1, 2) redistribution is covered under the GPL, but distribution of your design (case (3, 4)) is exempt from the GPL. This is the scheme which the pcb-fpw Project wishes to use for footprint distribution and use.

section.title: Introduction.
section.para: Footprint names can be derived by combining the name of the component category with a dimensional aspect of the component and the number of pins followed by a suffix derived from the environmental application.
If additional characteristcs are required they should be added as an alphabetical character, or combinations of characters that preceed the suffix.
Sample Name: QFP65P + Lead Span L1 X Lead Span L2 Nominal - Pin Qty
The + (plus sign) stands for "in addition to" (no space between the prefix and the body size).
The - (dash in bold typeface) is used to separate the pin quantity.
The _ (underscore in bold typeface) is the separator between pin Quantity in Hidden & Deleted pin components, and also used as a separator between lead numbers and package dimensions.
The X (capital letter X in bold typeface) is used instead of the word "by" to separate two numbers such as height X width like "Quad Packages".

section.title: Density Level Suffixes.
section.para: Suffixes for every common SMT footprint describe the environment application (this is the last character in every name).
This excludes the BGA which only comes in Nominal Environment Condition. Three footprint geometry variations are supplied for each of the device families;

listitem.para: maximum land protrusion (Density Level A).
median land protrusion (Density Level B).
minimum land protrusion (Density Level C).

section.para: Before adapting the minimum footprint variations the user should consider product qualification testing and the manufacturer's datasheets.

listitem.para: M - Density Level A: Maximum (Most) Land Protrusion.
For low-density product applications, the 'maximum' footprint condition has been developed to accommodate wave or flow solder of leadless chip devices and leaded gull- wing devices.
The geometry furnished for these devices, as well as inward and "J"-formed lead contact device families, may provide a wider process window for reflow solder processes as well.
N - Density Level B: Median (Nominal) Land Protrusion.
Products with a moderate level of component density may consider adapting the 'median' footprint geometry.

The median footprints furnished for all device families will provide a robust solder attachment condition for reflow solder processes and should provide a condition suitable for wave or reflow soldering of leadless chip and leaded gull-wing type devices.
L - Density Level C: Minimum (Least) Land Protrusion.
High component density typical of portable and hand-held product applications may consider the 'minimum' footprint geometry variation.
Selection of the minimum footprint geometry may not be suitable for all product use categories.

section.para: The use of classes of performance (1, 2, and 3) is combined with that of component density levels (A, B, and C) in explaining the condition of an electronic assembly.

As an example, combining the description as Levels 1A or 3B or 2C, would indicate the different combinations of performance and component density to aid in understanding the environment and the manufacturing requirements of a particular assembly.

section.title: Other Suffixes.
section.para: Heatsinks:
_HS - Footprint with Heat Sink attachment requiring additional holes or pads.
Example: TO254P1055X160_HS-6N.
Transistors:
_BEC - Base, Emitter and Collector (pin assignments used for three pin transistors).
_SGD - Source, Gate and Drain (pin assignments used for three pin transistors).
_213 - Alternate pin assignments used for three pin transistors.
Alternate Components that do not follow the JEDEC, EIA or IEC Standard:
A - Alternate Component (used primarily for SOP & QFP when Component Tolerance or Height is different).
B - Second Alternate Component.
Reverse Pin Order:
-20RN - 20 pin part, Reverse Pin Order, Nominal Environment.
Hidden Pins:
-20_24N - 20 pin part in a 24 pin package. The pins are numbered 1 - 24 the hidden pins are skipped. The schematic symbol displays up to 24 pins.
Deleted Pins:
-24_20N - 20 pin part in a 24 pin package. The pins are numbered 1 - 20. The schematic symbol displays 20 pins.
JEDEC and EIA Standard parts that have several alternate packages.
AA, AB, AC - JEDEC or EIA Component Identifier.
JEDEC or EIA component identifier: used primarily on chip resistors, inductors and capacitors.

appendix.title: PCB Glossary.
appendix.para: Now follow some used terms and their definitions in relation to the context of pcb, and the usage in pcb.

glossdef.para: A curved trace drawn on a drawing layer.

In reference to RS-274X files, an aperture is a brush shape used to draw things. Originally, the aperture was a physical hole of a specific shape and size through which light exposed a photographic film.

Varied meanings. Elements and boards may have attributes assigned to them, which are arbitrary mappings between a name and its value. pcb does not currently use those attributes itself. Within pcb an attribute is an arbitrary value passed between the core and the various HIDs, such as checkboxes and file names.

The most that the copper areas can be expanded before they are allowed to touch. For example, two 40 mil lines 10 mil apart can bloat up to (but not including) 5 mil before they touch, so the maximum bloat would be 4.99 mil.
The physical printed circuit board that is depicted by your layout. "Board" refers to the physical board, "layout" refers to the electronic data.
A thin layer of copper attached to a thin layer of insulator. Once etched, the remaining copper forms the electrical connections described by the layout file.
The distance beween the copper around a hole (the annulus) and the copper in the surrounding polygon, or between any other copper item (line or arc) and a surrounding polygon.

The area around an element which is still "used" by the element, for its electrical and mechanical clearance requirements. pcb does not use this term, nor explicitly support a courtyard definition for elements.

While designing your circuit board, pcb provides a number of layers to draw on. While it's convenient to think of each drawing layer as corresponding to one of the physical layers (copper, silk, etc), it's possible to group multiple drawing layers together into one physical layer, or assign drawing layers to purposes not corresponding to physical layers. For example, you could have two drawing layers corresponding to your ground plane copper layer, one for the ground plane itself and a second (differently colored) one for any signals that need to be routed on the ground plane layer.

Design Rule Check. In pcb your design is scanned and compared to a number of design rules, such as minimum trace thickness and spacing, and any violations are noted. Then, you are tortured to death with non-modal dialogs.

A computer-readable file intended to be used by automated drilling machines. The information includes drill diameters and locations. pcb may produce up to two drill files, one for plated holes and one for unplated holes. Automated drill machines were originally designed by the Excellon company, so drill files are sometimes called excellon files. Also called an NC drill file.

In pcb an element represents any part you might install on your board, such as resistors, capacitors, and integrated circuits. Note that this also includes anything on your board that has its own footprint, even if it doesn't have a part associated with it, such as test points, registration targets, and edge connectors. An element has a footprint, but is more than a footprint - it also has a reference designator (refdes), value, description, and location. "Footprint" refers to the pattern; "element" refers to the instance. For example, your layout might have four elements that use one footprint.
Not to be confused with solder resist, etch resist is used during the fabrication of the copper layers to define what copper is removed and what copper will remain.
See drill file.
A company that produces (fabricates) printed circuit boards from mechanical design files. Most accept (or expect) gerber (RS-274X) format files.
A drawing that shows a mechanical overview of the board, including the physical outline and all physical holes. This is often used by fabs to sanity check their interpretation of your design files.

A set of fiducials (typically 2, sometimes 3) can serve as a reference for a "Pick-and-Place" machine to accurately place parts on a pcb. Fiducials are free of solder mask and solder paste, as to provide a good contrast with the board materials to allow for proper optical recognition.

A footprint is the pattern on a circuit board to which your parts are attached. This includes all copper, silk, solder mask, and solder paste information. In other EDA programs, this may be referred to as a "land pattern". "Footprint" sometimes is used to refer to a footprint file. "Footprint" refers to the pattern; "element" refers to the instance in the pcb file. For example, your layout might have four elements that use one footprint.
A file that contains a single footprint definition. Normally, this means it describes one element, although there are exceptions.
A specification for the insulating layer used in printed circuit board manufacture. FR4 is the most common grade, and is often an epoxy fiberglass composite.
The GPL'd Electronic Design Automation suite of tools. See http://www.geda.seul.org. It includes, among other things, the gschem schematic editor, which produces input that pcb can use.
The common name for an RS-274X formatted file. Originally named after the Gerber Photoplotter Company.
The schematic editor that comes with gEDA.

A region created by the designer solely to prevent something else from existing there. For example, an element with a copper keepout would prevent the autorouter from routing traces through that area. pcb does not currently support keepouts.
See footprint.
There are two meanings of "layer'' in pcb. See "drawing layer" and "physical layer".

The board design information depicted by the edits you've made; this is what's stored in a pcb file and displayed on the screen. "Board" refers to the physical board, "layout" refers to the electronic data.
A straight segment drawn on a drawing layer.

Normally, pcb reports coordinates relative to the origin (upper left) of the board. However, you can designate a location on the board such that pcb also reports coordinates relative to that location. Such a location is the mark, and is drawn with an X shape. Elements also have a mark; this is the local origin from which other locations within the element are measured. Element marks are drawn as small diamonds.
See "solder mask".
A mil is 0.001 inch, or a "milli-inch". Other packages may call it a "thou", short for a thousandth of an inch (25.4 mm / 1000 = 0.0254 mm).
Numerically Controlled Drill file. See "drill file".

For most drawing layers, the stuff you draw corresponds to stuff that exists in a physical layer. For example, trace drawn on a copper layer results in copper existing on the board. For negative layers, however, what you draw results in what does not exist on the board. The solder mask gerber, for example, is such a layer - a circle drawn in the solder mask gerber results in a hole in the physical solder mask. pcb represents such layers in a meaningful way on the screen, but exporters may use a negative layer according to the needs of the fabrication process.

A list of symbolic electrical connections, normally provided as input to pcb from a schematic layout program, which represents the desired electrical connectivity of the board. pcb can compare the desired (loaded) netlist with the actual (copper) netlist and advise you of shorts or unrouted connections. If there are unrouted connections, it can use those to create a rat's nest to assist you in routing them.

The physical shape and dimension of your physical board. By default, this is a rectangle the size of your working area (the "board size"), but if you name one of the drawing layers "outline" that is used instead. While your board is itself a polygon shape, a polygon drawing object is not used to denote its outline - by convention, 10 mil (0.254 mm) wide lines are used to draw the outline, and the centerlines of those lines indicate the actual outline edges.
An electronic component can be packaged in one or more discrete forms, this is called a package.
An electrical connection to an element which does not require a through hole, for example as used by a surface mounted device.

A basic electronic element usually packaged in a discrete form with two or more connecting leads or metallic pads. Parts are intended to be connected together, usually by soldering to a printed circuit board, to create an electronic circuit with a particular function.
See "solder paste".
A thin sheet, usually plastic or metal and 0.002 to 0.005 inches thick, with holes where solder paste should be applied to your board.
A file used by pcb to store board layout. Such files end in ".pcb" and are normally readable (and editable) text files.

Internally, pcb maintains all measurements in its own units, typically with nanometer (nm) resolution, which is much smaller than both mils and millimeters. These are the default units used in pcb files. At the time this text was written. pcb-fpw stil uses units that are 1/100 of a mil, and pcb parses these as the old "no-units file format" units.

In the manufacture of circuit boards, a physical layer is, for example, each layer of copper, each side's silkscreen, the solder mask, the paste stencil, the physical outline, etc. Each physical layer requires a single layer definition to be produced by pcb; for professional fabs there is one gerber file for each physical layer.

An electrical connection to an element which requires a through hole, for example as needed by a DIP socket. Contrast with a pad. Note that pins and vias are mechanically identical, although pins default to untented while vias default to tented.

glossentry.glossterm: plated hole, plated through hole, PTH

glossdef.para: During fabrication, some holes become coated with copper which connects all the copper layers together at that point. Since this is normally done by electroplating, such holes are called "plated" holes, and normally have a copper annulus around them.

A polygon defines the ouline of a drawn region on a drawing layer. When used on a drawing layer representing a copper physical layer, it causes a copper polygon to exist in the final board, for example. Unlike lines and arcs, a polygon does not have a "thickness" as the lines define the exact boundary of the shape.
A special case of a polygon.
In pcb this usually means the etch resist.

A file format used originally by photoplotters, but now used by any machine used to fabricate circuit boards. The D variant requires a separate file defining all the apertures, and is considered obsolete. The X variant is newer and includes the aperture definitions. Since these formats were defined by the Gerber Photoplotter company, they are commonly known as "gerber files". Although there is no "owner" of the RS-274X spec, it can be found at various places online such as "http://www.artwork.com/gerber/274x/rs274xrevd_e.pdf".
The most that a copper area can decrease in size before it no longer touches (overlaps) an adjacent copper area.
A layer of ink or pigment drawn on the circuit board (usually, one for each side of the board) in order to include, for example, part numbers or element outlines.

A layer of heat resistant film placed over the outermost copper layers of your board, to prevent solder from sticking to any covered copper. When used to cover traces routed between pins or pads, this can help avoid shorts to those traces. Note that when shown in pcb the mask is drawn where the film exists, but when output (to postscript or gerber, for example), it is often "drawn" where the mask is to be removed.
See soldermask.

Ground up solder mixed with flux. This paste is normally squeegeed through a paste stencil to deposit a measured amount of paste on each pad on the board. Once the paste is applied, parts can be positioned on the paste, and the board heated - which melts the paste and solders the parts to the board.

When a circuit board is made with a solder mask, you have the option of opening a hole in the mask over vias, or leaving the solder mask intact over them. A via with an intact solder mask over it is tented, as the solder mask acts like a tent over the copper and hole.

Since copper is an efficient heat sink, connections to a large region of copper would be very difficult to solder - the copper heat sink prevents you from adequately heating the connection. To fix this, small cutouts are made around each such connection to create a thermal barrier, so that heat applied to the connection stays at the connection. Such a set of cutouts, and the copper bridges that remain, is called a "thermal". Thermals come in many patterns, which allows the designer to ensure adequate electrical connectivity and/or manufacturability.
In pcb this often refers to the width of a line or arc, not the thickness of the copper film used to produce the board. This is also the "size" of a line or arc.
See "mil".
A home-fabrication method that involves printing a layer with a laser printer, and transferring the toner from that print to an unetched copper board. The toner acts as an etch resist.
Any copper added to a copper layer whose purpose is to connect electrical signals between elements. Traces may be built up from lines, arcs, and polygons.

During fabrication, some holes are drilled after electroplating, and so do not receive the copper that would otherwise connect layers. Such holes are unplated holes, and normally do not have a copper annulus around them either.
When a hole is placed in the solder mask in order to expose a via below it, such a via is untented. Untented vias are available as test points or places to add wires later.
A via is a connection between different copper layers. In pcb all vias are "through" vias, in that they connect copper on all layers.

appendix.title: Pin/pad #1 locations.
appendix.para:
Following locations are given with regard to the top view:
Parts with two pins/pads: left pin/pad.
Parts with pins/pads on two sides: left side, top pin.
Parts with pins on four sides (for pin 1 on a corner): left side, top pin/pad.
Parts with pads on four sides (for pin 1 center): top side.
Pin Grid Arrays (PGA): left side, top pin.
Ball Grid Arrays (BGA): left side, top pad.
